text: Totally disagree with you there and I’ll tell you why. For example you could back every horse in a race 10 minutes before the start. If green up just before the off you’ll have some winners and some losers. If you’re looking at it and thinking “if only I could find out why the winners won”, then you’re fooling yourself.  It’s just the movement of the market, one moves down another moves up.

elements.text: Totally disagree with you there and I’ll tell you why. For example you could back every horse in a race 10 minutes before the start. text: I think <@U01A64T6DJQ>’s question about participant breakdown definitely has some basis. E.g. on some financial exchanges it is even possible to restrict matching against a set of cptys who you may believe is particularly sharp or have a post-trade profile that is quite poor/toxic. If you trade on shorter horizons you could benefit from not matching against such cptys. Anyways not that Betfair offer such functionality anyway, just a side point

text: :kissing_heart::two_hearts:

You guys think that the price movement of all horses from a race are correlated, or they movement are independent ?

I mean, it's plausible that a heavy back horse  always cause, as side effect, a upper price movement to other horses? 

I know that from a Bookmaker perspective, for sure. "They adjust the lines". But does the same occurs on exchanges?

I would think that this is how the other really big operators would work

text: The reasoning is that you use a model that prices the entire field. You back/lay anywhere you think you have a significant advantage, and it stands to reason that if you think a 1.50 runner should be at 1.30, a back. most of the rest of the field will be lays

elements.text: The reasoning is that you use a model that prices the entire field. You back/lay anywhere you think you have a significant advantage, and it stands to reason that if you think a 1.50 runner should be at 1.30, a back. most of the rest of the field will be lays

text: <@U016535QCJ2> I am surprised you don't look at horses more given this inside knowledge of how these big clients work. I mean you know that these orders are coming in and you know roughly when they will come and how they are filtered into the market. How are you not able to use this to your advantage? After all, as you say, YOU wrote the software so this must be a HUGE edge knowing that these price moves are coming? I realise without model parameters you won't know WHAT is going to be backed, but knowing how the orders are pushed through must mean you have sufficient knowledge to take advantage of this?

elements.text: I am surprised you don't look at horses more given this inside knowledge of how these big clients work. text: To expand with more description of your participants, if you're trading immediately (price taking) you're time-sensitive but not price sensitive. As liam says these folk will generally be either uninformed (punters) _or_ they have time-sensitive information (i.e they have figured something out that the market will discover soon). Conversely, folk who post prices are generally price sensitive but not time sensitive - they can be patient. They will often be value bettors who think the selection is value if the price gets to that level (this includes punters who want to bet on a horse but only at a certain price). Market makers are generally price sensitive, and bridge the gap between the price sensitive and the time sensitive by warehousing inventory through time to those who want to be able to execute immediately

elements.text: To expand with more description of your participants, if you're trading immediately (price taking) you're time-sensitive but not price sensitive. As liam says these folk will generally be either uninformed (punters)
or

they have time-sensitive information (i.e they have figured something out that the market will discover soon). Conversely, folk who post prices are generally price sensitive but not time sensitive - they can be patient. They will often be value bettors who think the selection is value if the price gets to that level (this includes punters who want to bet on a horse but only at a certain price). Market makers are generally price sensitive, and bridge the gap between the price sensitive and the time sensitive by warehousing inventory through time to those who want to be able to execute immediately

text: Nice explanation

elements.text: Nice explanation

text: Which kind of generally means you have those trading on expiring information (because they think the market will figure it out soon), and the completely clueless executing aggressively. If you're in-between these extremes you're executing more delicately (more passive orders). Being smarter means you get more lead-time on the market 'figuring out' what you know and you don't need to execute as aggressively, so you can get away with posting more vs executing immediately to get a slightly better price. Likewise, figuring things out quicker also gives you more lead-time to play more delicately.

elements.text: Which kind of generally means you have those trading on expiring information (because they think the market will figure it out soon), and the completely clueless executing aggressively. text:
I'm looking at one greyhound prices file and anyone knows how it's possible to have a lot of pre-racing traded volume with the pre-racing VWAP being 1?

It means that all the money was matched as BSP ?

elements.text:
I'm looking at one greyhound prices file and anyone knows how it's possible to have a lot of pre-racing traded volume with the pre-racing VWAP being 1?

It means that all the money was matched as BSP ?

text: Nope - probably either garbage data, or that the 'PPWAP' is calculated versus the market start time whereas the PPTRADED is everything before it either suspends or goes inplay - in which case it is explained by a market running late, which happens a lot in greyhounds (which typically trade in the last 1-2 minutes pre-race, so small amounts of being late could give a big change here)

elements.text: Nope - probably either garbage data, or that the 'PPWAP' is calculated versus the market start time whereas the PPTRADED is everything before it either suspends or goes inplay - in which case it is explained by a market running late, which happens a lot in greyhounds (which typically trade in the last 1-2 minutes pre-race, so small amounts of being late could give a big change here)
